Kayako - ticket id 60220701 // Syed Haider commented publicly: Dear Eshwar,

Thank you for joining me on the call today, and I sincerely apologize for the delayed response on this ticket.

During our session, we observed that the appliance was running slowly, and on reviewing the Status page, we noted a disk usage warning. To address this, we performed the following actions:

	*
Cleared excess snapshots and logs to free up disk space.

	*
Updated log rotation settings to retain only two log files instead of the default higher number.

	*
Reduced the disk usage threshold for logs under the /var partition.

After applying these configuration changes and deleting the unnecessary log files, we observed a significant improvement in appliance performance, resolving the lag that was present earlier. We also noted that the system health warning disappeared.

image

Upon inspecting your disk partitions, we noted that the log partition had very limited space available, while other partitions had unused disk space. I recommended resizing the log partition to a larger size. You can follow these instructions as referenced from https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/121027-edge-cache-crash-not-enough-disk-space: 

	* 
Go to Configuration > System > Setup > Storage.
	* 
Find an underused partition.
	* 
Remove the encryption on the partition and put the appliance into Bypass mode [https://192.168.206.189/admin/launch?script=rh&template=sys-network&tabsel=nics].
	* 
Change the size of the partition to a value that is greater than the 'Used' value, but reduce the size by a good amount, and click on "Resize".
	* 
After the status of the partition changes back to "Available" you should be able to see how much space was removed from the partition to show up in 'unallocated storage'.
	* 
Change the size of the logs partition adding that unallocated storage space, click on "Resize" and wait.
	* 
It is recommended to wait at least 5 minutes for the graphs to show up. If the graphs are not back, we recommend a reboot of the Exinda appliance.

-------------------------

Regarding the slowness issue you experienced (which is currently no longer occurring):

If this problem reappears, please raise a new ticket and include a system dump from your appliance, along with relevant context. We are eager to investigate any version-related performance issues. Having the system dump will allow us to engage our development team effectively with concrete evidence.

-------------------------

Once again, I apologize for the delay in our initial response. I have flagged this for our management team to ensure you receive faster support in the future. Your feedback is greatly appreciated and helps us improve.

Please feel free to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.

Best regards,
Syed Haider
GFI - Exinda Network Orchestrator Support Team

This ticket will stay open for one week unless you reply with "This ticket can be closed" or update the status to Completed in the portal. We will write to you again to remind you.

#60192334 [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/conversation/view/60192334], I've identified some specific concerns:*" data-section-index="27">From the diagnostic output you provided in ticket #60192334 [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/conversation/view/60192334], I've identified some specific concerns: 1. The /var/home/root/dead.letters directory is consuming 8.5GB - This is abnormal and suggests a mail/notification configuration issue that needs to be addressed at the root cause level. 2. TMS snapshot staging files (2.9GB) are not being cleaned up properly.
To properly resolve this recurring issue, I need you to run the following commands and provide the output:
ls -lh /var/home/root/dead.letters | head -20

find /var/opt/tms/snapshots/.staging -type f -mtime +7 -ls

cat /var/log/messages | grep -i "mail\|dead.letter" | tail -50

To ensure there are no further underlying issues, please follow Gathering Files for Troubleshooting (Diagnostics/Sysdump and PDF Report) - Exinda [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117237-gathering-files-for-troubleshooting-diagnostics-sysdump-and-pdf-report] to provide the sysdump and PDF report.

Additionally, given the recurring nature of this issue and your previous request, I'd like to schedule a WebEx session to investigate this in real-time and ensure we address the root cause, not just the symptoms.

Please provide:

	* The command outputs above
	* Your availability for a WebEx session this week
	* Any changes made to mail/notification settings or TMS configurations*

IMMEDIATE NEXT STEPS:

1. ACKNOWLEDGE THE RECURRING NATURE

 The customer has already followed the standard article and the issue persists. The support team needs to move beyond the standard troubleshooting steps. 

2. INVESTIGATE ROOT CAUSE - NOT JUST SYMPTOMS

 Based on the diagnostic output from the previous ticket, there are specific areas that need attention: Critical Finding: /var/home/root/dead.letters is consuming 8.5GB - this is abnormal and indicates: 

 	* Email/notification delivery failures
 	* Possible mail configuration issues
 	* Potential system misconfigurations

 Actions needed: - Investigate what's causing files to accumulate in dead.letters- Check mail/notification configuration- Examine why TMS snapshots are staging and not completing (2.9GB in .staging)- Review snapshot retention policies 

3. SPECIFIC TECHNICAL STEPS TO REQUEST:

 Phase 1: Immediate Investigation 

 	* Run ls -lh /var/home/root/dead.letters | head -20 to see what type of files are accumulating
 	* Check TMS snapshot configuration and why staging files aren't being cleaned
 	* Review system logs for mail delivery errors or notification failures
 	* Check if there are any scheduled jobs failing

 Phase 2: Remediation 

 	* Safely remove dead.letters content (after backing up a sample for analysis)
 	* Clean up old TMS snapshots and adjust retention settings
 	* Fix any mail/notification configuration issues
 	* Implement proper log rotation if not configured

4. ADDRESS PERFORMANCE ISSUES SEPARATELY

 The disk space issue may be contributing to performance problems, but there could be other factors related to the v7.6.0 upgrade that need investigation. 

5. RECOMMENDED RESPONSE:

 The support team should send a message like:

--- AI Assistant ---

 Thanks for letting me know you’re experiencing a performance issue with Exinda Network Orchestrator. Let’s get this sorted out!

To help pinpoint the cause, could you tell me a bit more about what you’re seeing? For example:

 	* Is the device running slow overall, or are specific features (like reporting, traffic shaping, or the web UI) affected?
 	* Have you noticed high CPU or memory usage, or any error messages?
 	* When did the performance issue start, and has anything changed in your network or configuration recently?

Once I have a bit more detail, I can guide you through some targeted troubleshooting steps. 

--- Customer (Eswaramoorthy P) ---

 Exinda Network Orchestrator Performance Issue and the disk space is full. 

--- AI Assistant ---

 Thanks for sharing those details! When the disk space is full on Exinda Network Orchestrator, it can definitely cause performance issues, prevent upgrades, and even make monitoring data unavailable. Here’s what you can do to resolve this:

STEP-BY-STEP: FREE UP DISK SPACE

 	* Delete Unnecessary Files via Web UI

- Go to Configuration > Diagnostics > Diagnostics.
- In the Diagnostic Files table, select all files you don’t need (like old sysdumps).
- Click “Remove Files.”
- Repeat for the System Snapshot Files and TCP Dump Files tables.
- Also check Configuration > Diagnostics > TCP Dump for any old TCP dump files to remove.
- For more details, see: 'No policy' Shown in Real-Time Monitoring and Optimizer Not Capturing Traffic [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/119390]

 	* Check Which Partition is Full

- If you’re comfortable with the CLI, log in via SSH and run:

     df -h
     

- This will show which partition (often /var) is full.
- For more info on diagnosing and solving disk space issues, check: Exinda - System Disk Full alert or not enough disk space available [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/121300]

 	* Format the Full Partition (if needed)

- Go to System > Setup > Storage in the Web UI.
- Format the partition that’s full (only if you’re sure you don’t need the data).
- If you can’t find the partition under warning, or if you’re unsure, please contact Exinda support.
- More details here: Disk Usage High [https://support.exinda.gfi.com/article/117230]

 	* Restart the Optimizer or Reboot

- After clearing space, restart the optimizer.
- If issues persist, try rebooting the Exinda: Configuration > Maintenance > Reboot / Shutdown. 
-------------------------
 If you follow these steps and the disk is still full or the system remains slow, let me know! I can guide you through more advanced troubleshooting or help you get in touch with a live support agent if needed.

Would you like to start with the Web UI cleanup, or do you need help with the CLI commands?
